title: Respite for dairy farmers as supermarkets agree to pay more for milk
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Aug 14, 2015, 21:06 BST - UK Markets closed Respite for dairy farmers as supermarkets agree to pay more for milk By Emily Gosden | Telegraph – 29 minutes ago +0.0194 
Farmers welcome improved deals from Aldi, Lidl, Morrisons and Asda 
Britain’s struggling dairy farmers have been offered some respite after a string of supermarkets bowed to pressure to improve the amount they paid processors for milk. 
Aldi, Lidl and Morrisons on Friday all made new commitments to pay a minimum level for their milk, following a similar move by Asda on Thursday night. 
Morrisons committed to pay at least 26 pence per litre, while Aldi and Lidl moved to 28p, matching the level set by Asda. 
The moves follow a week in which dairy farmers herded cattle through supermarkets in protest at low prices they were receiving for their milk they produce. 
Farmers say they have been receiving less than 24p for milk that ends up on these supermarket shelves well below break-even prices estimated at between 28 and 30p. 
By contrast some supermarkets including Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) , Sainsbury’s, Waitrose and Marks and Spencer have deals in place to pay at least 30p per litre. 
Meurig Raymond, the National Farmers Union President, warned earlier this week that farmers were “haemorrhaging” money and said more than 250 dairy farmers had already quit so far this year in the worst crisis he had ever seen for the industry . 
Exactly how much better off farmers will be following the raft of new pledges by discount supermarkets on Thursday and Friday is unclear because their milk is generally bought via large milk processing companies. 
Prices paid to the processors previously, and the exact amount farmers receive, have not been disclosed. 
However farming groups including the National Farmers Union, which was involved in the negotiations over the new prices, welcomed the commitments. 
A spokesman for Aldi confirmed that its price change, which comes into effect on Monday, would "result in a higher price being paid to farmers". 
Lidl’s 28p floor comes into effect on Monday, as does Asda’s. The NFU said that Asda would “pay 28p per litre to processor Arla, which will then be expected to pass this onto its British farmer suppliers”. 
Morrisons’ price increase will come into effect “later this month and through the winter,” it said. 
Earlier this week Morrisons launched a new ‘Milk for Farmers’ brand, selling its usual milk under different packaging for 10p per litre more and pledging to give the extra cash to farmers . 
The NFU said it had been “explaining the dire straits that many farmers are facing to the public and to retailers” and had received “overwhelming public support from the general public”. 
It said Lidl was “taking action to help ensure farmers get a fair price”, Asda had “moved to support farmers in their hour of need”, Aldi had “shown it supports the farming community” and Morrisons had “recognised the need to support the dairy sector at this difficult time”. 
Morrisons also announced plans for a new cheddar cheese line at a 34 pence premium, with the extra cash going to farmers. 
Reasons for the low milk prices have been contentious. Supermarkets point to a supply glut, caused in part by Russian import restrictions. 
But farmers have blamed supermarkets for slashing their milk prices in an attempt to compete with each other. 
Dairy prices are expected to fall further following the abolition of European milk production quotas, which took effect from April. 
While UK production has been unconstrained by the quota system, milk production across the continent and Ireland (Other OTC: IRLD - news ) is widely expected to ramp up, potentially leading to a greater volume of imports into the domestic market.
